content:
An
 
Analytical
 
Overview
 
of
 
Dan
 
Klein,
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara,
 
and
 
Their
 
Lead
 
Generation
 
Enterprise
 
I.
 
Executive
 
Summary
 
This
 
report
 
provides
 
a
 
comprehensive
 
analysis
 
of
 
business
 
partners
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
and
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara,
 
their
 
individual
 
entrepreneurial
 
journeys,
 
their
 
collaborative
 
lead
 
generation
 
coaching
 
business,
 
and
 
associated
 
ventures.
 
Dan
 
Klein,
 
positioned
 
as
 
"The
 
OG
 
Lead
 
Gen
 
Coach"
 
with
 
a
 
reported
 
net
 
worth
 
of
 
$30
 
million
 
1
,
 
brings
 
decades
 
of
 
diverse
 
business
 
experience,
 
including
 
a
 
significant
 
reported
 
windfall
 
from
 
PPE
 
sales
 
during
 
the
 
COVID-19
 
pandemic.
1
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara,
 
a
 
former
 
student
 
of
 
Klein,
 
has
 
rapidly
 
ascended
 
to
 
become
 
a
 
lead
 
generation
 
expert
 
and
 
a
 
key
 
partner,
 
with
 
a
 
reported
 
net
 
worth
 
of
 
$5
 
million
 
and
 
substantial
 
monthly
 
income
 
from
 
his
 
digital
 
assets
 
and
 
influential
 
blog,
 
Ippei.com.
2
 
Their
 
core
 
business
 
revolves
 
around
 
a
 
local
 
lead
 
generation
 
model,
 
teaching
 
students
 
to
 
build
 
and
 
rank
 
websites
 
for
 
local
 
businesses,
 
creating
 
"digital
 
properties"
 
that
 
generate
 
recurring
 
income.
3
 
This
 
model
 
is
 
promoted
 
for
 
its
 
high
 
profit
 
margins
 
and
 
potential
 
for
 
passive
 
income.
5
 
Their
 
flagship
 
coaching
 
program,
 
formerly
 
known
 
as
 
"JobKilling"
 
and
 
now
 
often
 
referred
 
to
 
as
 
the
 
JK
 
program
 
or
 
associated
 
with
 
Snapps.ai
 
coaching,
 
has
 
reportedly
 
enrolled
 
over
 
7,500
 
students.
2
 
It
 
is
 
a
 
high-ticket
 
offering,
 
with
 
costs
 
reportedly
 
ranging
 
from
 
$5,000
 
to
 
over
 
$9,000
 
2
,
 
promising
 
comprehensive
 
training,
 
extensive
 
support,
 
and
 
access
 
to
 
a
 
large
 
community.
 
The
 
partnership
 
appears
 
synergistic,
 
with
 
Klein
 
providing
 
overarching
 
business
 
strategy
 
and
 
mentorship,
 
while
 
Kanehara
 
offers
 
specialized
 
SEO
 
expertise
 
and
 
a
 
compelling
 
student-to-success
 
narrative.
3
 
Associated
 
ventures
 
include
 
Snapps.ai,
 
an
 
AI-powered
 
website
 
builder
 
that
 
also
 
serves
 
as
 
the
 
coaching
 
hub
 
7
,
 
and
 
Ippei.com,
 
a
 
highly
 
profitable
 
blog
 
that
 
funnels
 
leads
 
to
 
their
 
program.
2
 
Public
 
perception
 
is
 
mixed.
 
Numerous
 
testimonials
 
attest
 
to
 
life-changing
 
success
 
7
,
 
while
 
criticisms
 
point
 
to
 
the
 
high
 
cost,
 
questionable
 
value
 
by
 
some,
 
aggressive
 
sales
 
tactics,
 
and
 
past
 
unresolved
 
complaints
 
against
 
the
 
"JobKilling"
 
brand.
8
 
The
 
enterprise
 
demonstrates
 
considerable
 
financial
 
success
 
and
 
market
 
influence,
 
having
 
even
 
trained
 
individuals
 
who
 
subsequently
 
became
 
competitors.
2
 
Key
 
strategic
 
elements
 
include
 
the
 
powerful
 
"digital
 
real
 
estate"
 
concept,
 
the
 
integrated
 
ecosystem
 
of
 
coaching
 
and
 
proprietary
 
tools,
 
and
 
the
 
compelling
 
narrative
 
of
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara's
 
success.
 
However,
 
vulnerabilities
 
exist,
 
notably
 
the
 
reliance
 
on
 
Google's
 
algorithms,
 
the
 
reputational
 
impact
 
of
 
negative
 
feedback,
 
and
 
the
 
challenge
 
of
 
maintaining
 
value
 
perception
 
for
 
a
 
high-cost
 
program
 
in
 
an
 
increasingly
 
competitive
 
market.
 
The
 
long-term
 
sustainability
 
of
 
their
 
guru-led
 
model
 
and
 
the
 
balance
 
between
 
empowering
 
students
 
and
 
fostering
 
dependency
 
on
 
their
 
ecosystem
 
are
 
also
 
pertinent
 
considerations.
 
This
 
report
 
synthesizes
 
publicly
 
available
 
information
 
to
 
offer
 
a
 
nuanced
 
understanding
 
of
 
their
 
operations,
 
market
 
standing,
 
and
 
the
 
strategic
 
factors
 
underpinning
 
their
 
enterprise.
 
II.
 
Subject
 
Profile:
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
–
 
"The
 
OG
 
Lead
 
Gen
 
Coach"
 
A.
 
Background
 
and
 
Entrepreneurial
 
Journey
 
(Pre-Lead
 
Gen,
 
PPE
 
Venture)
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
is
 
presented
 
as
 
a
 
highly
 
experienced
 
entrepreneur,
 
with
 
a
 
business
 
career
 
spanning
 
over
 
15
 
years
 
prior
 
to
 
his
 
pronounced
 
focus
 
on
 
internet-based
 
ventures.
1
 
His
 
early
 
entrepreneurial
 
activities
 
were
 
rooted
 
in
 
traditional,
 
tangible
 
businesses.
 
These
 
included
 
owning
 
a
 
window
 
tinting
 
business,
 
a
 
coupon-based
 
enterprise,
 
real
 
estate
 
ventures,
 
and
 
notably,
 
a
 
Dutch
 
Bros
 
Coffee
 
franchise.
1
 
This
 
diverse
 
portfolio
 
suggests
 
a
 
foundational
 
understanding
 
of
 
varied
 
operational
 
models
 
and
 
market
 
dynamics,
 
which
 
likely
 
informed
 
his
 
later
 
transition
 
into
 
the
 
digital
 
business
 
landscape.
 
While
 
the
 
claim
 
regarding
 
ownership
 
of
 
a
 
Dutch
 
Bros
 
Coffee
 
franchise
 
is
 
part
 
of
 
his
 
official
 
biography
 
1
,
 
independent
 
corroboration
 
was
 
not
 
available
 
in
 
the
 
provided
 
information.
11
 
A
 
pivotal
 
event
 
in
 
Klein's
 
recent
 
financial
 
history
 
is
 
his
 
reported
 
involvement
 
in
 
the
 
Personal
 
Protective
 
Equipment
 
(PPE)
 
market
 
during
 
the
 
COVID-19
 
pandemic.
 
He
 
is
 
said
 
to
 
have
 
amassed
 
$30
 
million
 
through
 
dealing
 
in
 
PPE
 
masks
 
and
 
gowns
 
during
 
this
 
period.
1
 
This
 
venture
 
underscores
 
an
 
agile
 
and
 
opportunistic
 
approach
 
to
 
business,
 
capitalizing
 
on
 
a
 
period
 
of
 
critical
 
market
 
demand.
 
The
 
timeline
 
of
 
this
 
reported
 
success
 
aligns
 
with
 
documented
 
surges
 
in
 
PPE
 
prices
 
in
 
early
 
2020
 
due
 
to
 
global
 
supply
 
chain
 
disruptions
 
and
 
heightened
 
demand.
13
 
This
 
substantial
 
influx
 
of
 
capital
 
could
 
have
 
significantly
 
fueled
 
the
 
expansion
 
and
 
scaling
 
of
 
his
 
subsequent
 
and
 
ongoing
 
business
 
activities,
 
particularly
 
in
 
the
 
lead
 
generation
 
coaching
 
sphere.
 
Furthermore,
 
such
 
a
 
significant
 
financial
 
achievement
 
outside
 
the
 
realm
 
of
 
online
 
coaching
 
could
 
serve
 
as
 
a
 
potent
 
marketing
 
tool,
 
bolstering
 
his
 
credibility
 
as
 
a
 
versatile
 
business
 
expert
 
capable
 
of
 
navigating
 
diverse
 
and
 
high-stakes
 
markets.
 
His
 
current
 
reported
 
net
 
worth
 
stands
 
at
 
$30
 
million
 
1
,
 
a
 
figure
 
that
 
positions
 
him
 
as
 
a
 
high-net-worth
 
individual,
 
with
 
the
 
PPE
 
venture
 
likely
 
being
 
a
 
substantial
 
contributor
 
to
 
this
 
valuation.
 
The
 
transition
 
from
 
managing
 
"non-internet
 
businesses"
 
to
 
spearheading
 
online
 
lead
 
generation
 
coaching
 
reflects
 
a
 
broader
 
economic
 
shift
 
towards
 
digital
 
enterprises.
 
This
 
evolution
 
suggests
 
Klein
 
possesses
 
an
 
ability
 
to
 
adapt
 
to
 
changing
 
market
 
conditions
 
and
 
identify
 
emerging
 
lucrative
 
opportunities.
 
His
 
experience
 
in
 
traditional
 
businesses
 
may
 
also
 
provide
 
a
 
unique
 
perspective
 
in
 
his
 
coaching,
 
potentially
 
grounding
 
digital
 
strategies
 
with
 
established
 
business
 
principles.
 
However,
 
success
 
in
 
the
 
digital
 
coaching
 
arena
 
often
 
demands
 
distinct
 
skill
 
sets,
 
including
 
sophisticated
 
online
 
marketing,
 
personal
 
branding,
 
and
 
community
 
management,
 
which
 
differ
 
from
 
those
 
required
 
for
 
traditional
 
brick-and-mortar
 
operations.
 
B.
 
Expertise
 
and
 
Role
 
in
 
Lead
 
Generation
 
Coaching
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
is
 
prominently
 
branded
 
as
 
"The
 
OG
 
Lead
 
Gen
 
Coach,"
 
a
 
title
 
suggesting
 
he
 
is
 
a
 
foundational
 
figure
 
or
 
pioneer
 
within
 
the
 
lead
 
generation
 
coaching
 
niche.
 
He
 
reportedly
 
commenced
 
coaching
 
in
 
this
 
specific
 
field
 
in
 
2014.
1
 
His
 
partner,
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara,
 
refers
 
to
 
him
 
as
 
the
 
"brain
 
behind
 
Lead
 
Generation".
3
 
The
 
coaching
 
program
 
they
 
jointly
 
lead
 
is
 
described
 
as
 
having
 
been
 
operational
 
for
 
over
 
a
 
decade
 
7
,
 
further
 
supporting
 
Klein's
 
claim
 
to
 
extensive
 
experience
 
in
 
this
 
domain.
 
His
 
coaching
 
style
 
is
 
depicted
 
as
 
multifaceted:
 
talented,
 
dynamic,
 
capable
 
of
 
delivering
 
valuable
 
insights,
 
highly
 
motivational,
 
and
 
possessing
 
a
 
sense
 
of
 
humor.
1
 
Beyond
 
his
 
coaching
 
persona,
 
he
 
is
 
characterized
 
as
 
an
 
8-figure
 
serial
 
entrepreneur
 
who
 
imparts
 
knowledge
 
on
 
scaling
 
businesses
 
and
 
implementing
 
automation
 
strategies.
7
 
This
 
portrayal
 
emphasizes
 
not
 
only
 
his
 
business
 
acumen
 
but
 
also
 
his
 
capacity
 
to
 
engage,
 
inspire,
 
and
 
effectively
 
transfer
 
complex
 
information
 
to
 
students—qualities
 
essential
 
for
 
a
 
successful
 
coach
 
in
 
a
 
competitive
 
online
 
education
 
market.
 
The
 
operational
 
structure
 
of
 
the
 
coaching
 
program
 
appears
 
to
 
involve
 
his
 
family.
 
His
 
wife,
 
Tori,
 
and
 
their
 
children
 
are
 
mentioned
 
as
 
being
 
involved
 
and
 
supportive.
1
 
Tori
 
Klein,
 
in
 
particular,
 
is
 
highlighted
 
by
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara
 
as
 
being
 
"incredibly
 
supportive
 
and
 
instrumental
 
in
 
the
 
coaching
 
program's
 
operations".
1
 
This
 
family
 
involvement
 
can
 
cultivate
 
an
 
image
 
of
 
a
 
dedicated,
 
mission-driven
 
family
 
business.
 
While
 
this
 
can
 
foster
 
trust
 
and
 
a
 
sense
 
of
 
shared
 
purpose,
 
family-run
 
enterprises
 
can
 
also
 
encounter
 
challenges
 
related
 
to
 
professional
 
management
 
structures,
 
objective
 
decision-making,
 
and
 
long-term
 
scalability
 
if
 
not
 
managed
 
with
 
clear
 
governance.
 
However,
 
the
 
positive
 
portrayal
 
of
 
Tori's
 
significant
 
operational
 
role
 
suggests
 
she
 
is
 
a
 
key
 
contributor
 
to
 
the
 
program's
 
functionality.
 
C.
 
Reported
 
Business
 
Philosophy
 
and
 
Character
 
From
 
the
 
perspective
 
of
 
his
 
primary
 
business
 
partner,
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara,
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
is
 
held
 
in
 
high
 
esteem
 
not
 
only
 
for
 
his
 
business
 
acumen
 
but
 
also
 
for
 
his
 
personal
 
character.
 
Kanehara
 
attributes
 
to
 
Klein
 
a
 
strong
 
moral
 
code,
 
an
 
outspoken
 
nature,
 
and
 
a
 
leadership
 
style
 
rooted
 
in
 
leading
 
by
 
example
 
through
 
diligent
 
work.
1
 
This
 
viewpoint,
 
originating
 
from
 
a
 
close
 
associate,
 
paints
 
a
 
picture
 
of
 
a
 
principled
 
and
 
dedicated
 
leader.
 
Klein's
 
mentorship
 
is
 
credited
 
with
 
extending
 
beyond
 
mere
 
business
 
tactics.
 
It
 
reportedly
 
teaches
 
students,
 
including
 
Kanehara
 
himself,
 
crucial
 
life
 
skills
 
such
 
as
 
how
 
to
 
confront
 
fears,
 
resist
 
making
 
excuses,
 
and
 
maintain
 
commitment
 
to
 
goals
 
and
 
objectives.
1
 
This
 
approach
 
is
 
said
 
to
 
lead
 
to
 
significant
 
personal
 
growth
 
that
 
transcends
 
financial
 
or
 
business
 
achievements.
 
Such
 
an
 
emphasis
 
on
 
mindset
 
and
 
personal
 
development
 
is
 
a
 
common
 
and
 
often
 
highly
 
valued
 
component
 
of
 
high-ticket
 
coaching
 
programs,
 
which
 
aim
 
to
 
offer
 
transformative
 
experiences
 
rather
 
than
 
just
 
skill
 
acquisition.
 
III.
 
Subject
 
Profile:
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara
 
–
 
From
 
Novice
 
to
 
Lead
 
Gen
 
Expert
 
A.
 
Background
 
and
 
Entry
 
into
 
Online
 
Business
 
(Education,
 
Early
 
Career)
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara's
 
narrative
 
is
 
one
 
of
 
transformation
 
from
 
an
 
"average
 
guy"
 
who
 
was
 
reportedly
 
"broke"
 
to
 
a
 
successful
 
online
 
entrepreneur.
3
 
He
 
is
 
a
 
graduate
 
of
 
Michigan
 
State
 
University,
 
where
 
he
 
earned
 
a
 
degree
 
in
 
advertising.
2
 
This
 
educational
 
background
 
in
 
advertising
 
provides
 
a
 
relevant
 
foundation
 
for
 
a
 
career
 
in
 
online
 
marketing
 
and
 
digital
 
business.
 
The
 
"average
 
guy"
 
persona
 
is
 
a
 
frequently
 
employed
 
and
 
effective
 
marketing
 
strategy
 
in
 
the
 
online
 
coaching
 
industry,
 
as
 
it
 
makes
 
the
 
prospect
 
of
 
significant
 
success
 
appear
 
more
 
attainable
 
to
 
a
 
broad
 
audience.
 
Prior
 
to
 
his
 
foray
 
into
 
online
 
ventures,
 
Kanehara
 
worked
 
in
 
what
 
he
 
describes
 
as
 
an
 
unfulfilling
 
office
 
job
 
at
 
a
 
Japanese
 
automotive
 
car
 
parts
 
company,
 
earning
 
a
 
modest
 
salary.
2
 
This
 
experience
 
of
 
dissatisfaction
 
with
 
traditional
 
employment
 
serves
 
as
 
a
 
relatable
 
motivating
 
factor
 
for
 
many
 
individuals
 
seeking
 
alternative
 
income
 
opportunities
 
online.
 
His
 
journey
 
into
 
the
 
digital
 
business
 
world
 
involved
 
exploring
 
several
 
prevalent
 
models,
 
including
 
Amazon
 
FBA,
 
dropshipping,
 
affiliate
 
marketing,
 
and
 
providing
 
SEO
 
and
 
paid
 
advertising
 
services.
3
 
According
 
to
 
his
 
accounts,
 
his
 
significant
 
breakthrough
 
occurred
 
in
 
2014
 
when
 
he
 
discovered
 
the
 
local
 
lead
 
generation
 
business
 
model.
5
 
This
 
exploration
 
phase,
 
culminating
 
in
 
the
 
adoption
 
of
 
lead
 
generation,
 
is
 
often
 
presented
 
as
 
a
 
process
 
of
 
discerning
 
the
 
most
 
effective
 
and
 
rewarding
 
online
 
business
 
strategy,
 
which
 
he
 
now
 
champions
 
and
 
teaches.
 
B.
 
Mastery
 
of
 
Lead
 
Generation
 
and
 
SEO
 
The
 
pivotal
 
moment
 
in
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara's
 
career
 
trajectory
 
was
 
his
 
decision
 
to
 
join
 
a
 
Lead
 
Generation
 
coaching
 
program
 
in
 
2014,
 
which
 
was
 
then
 
run
 
by
 
Dan
 
Klein
 
and
 
Brad
 
Campbell.
2
 
This
 
marked
 
his
 
formal
 
entry
 
into
 
the
 
field
 
and
 
directly
 
connected
 
his
 
learning
 
path
 
to
 
Dan
 
Klein's
 
methodologies.
 
He
 
began
 
by
 
building
 
his
 
initial
 
lead
 
generation
 
websites
 
in
 
various
 
local
 
service
 
niches,
 
such
 
as
 
tree
 
care,
 
limousine
 
services,
 
and
 
towing,
 
primarily
 
across
 
Michigan.
2
 
His
 
early
 
efforts
 
reportedly
 
yielded
 
rapid
 
success.
 
Within
 
seven
 
months
 
of
 
joining
 
the
 
program,
 
in
 
April
 
2015,
 
Kanehara
 
quit
 
his
 
full-time
 
job
 
to
 
dedicate
 
himself
 
entirely
 
to
 
his
 
burgeoning
 
lead
 
generation
 
business.
2
 
Over
 
the
 
subsequent
 
three
 
years,
 
he
 
successfully
 
scaled
 
this
 
venture
 
to
 
generate
 
a
 
recurring
 
monthly
 
income
 
of
 
$30,000.
2
 
This
 
narrative
 
of
 
swift
 
financial
 
achievement
 
serves
 
as
 
a
 
powerful
 
testimonial
 
for
 
both
 
the
 
efficacy
 
of
 
the
 
lead
 
generation
 
model
 
and
 
the
 
coaching
 
program
 
he
 
attended.
 
Currently,
 
Kanehara
 
is
 
reported
 
to
 
own
 
over
 
50
 
lead
 
generation
 
websites,
 
with
 
each
 
site
 
purportedly
 
earning
 
between
 
$500
 
and
 
$2,500
 
per
 
month,
 
providing
 
him
 
with
 
a
 
substantial
 
source
 
of
 
long-term
 
passive
 
income.
3
 
More
 
recent
 
information
 
suggests
 
his
 
portfolio
 
of
 
lead
 
generation
 
properties
 
generates
 
over
 
$50,000
 
per
 
month.
2
 
The
 
difference
 
in
 
these
 
figures
 
may
 
be
 
attributable
 
to
 
the
 
differing
 
publication
 
dates
 
of
 
the
 
source
 
materials,
 
with
 
the
 
higher
 
figure
 
from
 
a
 
more
 
recent
 
source
 
2
 
likely
 
reflecting
 
continued
 
growth.
 
His
 
proficiency
 
in
 
this
 
domain
 
has
 
established
 
him
 
as
 
an
 
expert
 
in
 
website
 
ranking
 
strategies
 
and
 
the
 
generation
 
of
 
free
 
organic
 
traffic,
 
and
 
he
 
is
 
responsible
 
for
 
teaching
 
high-level
 
Search
 
Engine
 
Optimization
 
(SEO)
 
techniques
 
within
 
the
 
coaching
 
program
 
he
 
co-leads.
2
 
This
 
positions
 
him
 
as
 
the
 
primary
 
technical
 
SEO
 
specialist
 
within
 
the
 
partnership.
 
C.
 
Ippei.com:
 
Platform
 
and
 
Revenue
 
Stream
 
Ippei.com
 
is
 
a
 
significant
 
digital
 
asset
 
developed
 
and
 
managed
 
by
 
Ippei
 
Kanehara.
 
This
 
blog
 
serves
 
as
 
a
 
platform
 
where
 
he
 
publishes
 
reviews
 
of
 
various
 
online
 
courses
 
and
 
business
 
models,
 
consistently
 
framing
 
them
 
in
 
comparison
 
to
 
the
 
local
 
lead
 
generation
 
model
 
he
 
advocates.
2
 
The
 
content
 
strategy
 
of
 
Ippei.com
 
appears
 
designed
 
to
 
position
 
their
 
preferred
 
model,
 
and
 
by
 
extension
 
their
 
coaching
 
program,
 
as
 
superior
 
to
 
alternatives.
 
Beyond
 
its
 
role
 
as
 
a
 
content
 
marketing
 
tool,
 
Ippei.com
 
is
 
also
 
a
 
substantial
 
revenue
 
generator
 
in
 
its
 
own
 
right,
 
reportedly
 
earning
 
six-figures
 
in
 
revenue
 
each
 
month.
2
 
This
 
income
 
is
 
likely
 
derived
 
from
 
a
 
combination
 
of
 
affiliate
 
marketing
 
activities
 
and
 
direct
 
lead
 
generation
 
for
 
their
 
own
 
coaching
 
services.
 
Through
 
this
 
platform,
 
Kanehara
 
also
 
shares
 
his
 
research,
 
insights,
 
and
 
practical
 
tips
 
on
 
various
 
online
 
business
 
strategies.
3
 
The
 
strategic
 
construction
 
of
 
Ippei.com
 
into
 
a
 
high-traffic,
 
authoritative
 
voice
 
in
 
the
 
"make
 
money
 
online"
 
niche
 
allows
 
Kanehara
 
and
 
Klein
 
to
 
control
 
the
 
narrative
 
around
 
their
 
business
 
model.
 
By
 
systematically
 
reviewing
 
and
 
often
 
critiquing
 
competing
 
online
 
business
 
opportunities,
 
the
 
blog
 
effectively
 
pre-sells
 
visitors
 
on
 
the
 
merits
 
of
 
local
 
lead
 
generation.
 
This
 
sophisticated
 
inbound
 
marketing
 
approach
 
likely
 
plays
 
a
 
crucial
 
role
 
in
 
funneling
 
qualified
 
and
 
pre-disposed
 
leads
 
towards
 
their
 
high-ticket
 
coaching
 
program.

This

around
 
2014-2015,
 
underscores
 
the
 
financial

he
 
attributes
 
to
 
the
 
business

his

partnership
 
with
 
Dan

His
 
notable
 
achievements
 
as
 
a

of
 
Dan

His

in

in

and

then

as
 
JK
 
(JobKilling).
2
 
He

Dan
 
Klein's
 
"right-hand
 
man"
 
2
,
 
signifying
 
a

from

in

This
 
progression
 
from

to

and
 
then
 
to
 
partner
 
is
 
a

and

It

for

suggesting
 
that
 
exceptional

and

opportunities
 
are
 
within

for
 
dedicated
 
students.
 
This
 
carefully
 
crafted
 
"everyman"
 
to
 
"expert"
 
storyline,
 
potentially
 
enhanced
 
by
 
Kanehara's
 
advertising
 
degree,
 
is
 
a
 
powerful
 
tool
 
for
 
attracting
 
aspiring
 
entrepreneurs
 
to
 
their
 
offerings.

Partnership:

Q&A 1  Q: How does it work? Do you show me how to build the website and everything? A: Yes, we're teaching you how to do everything 100 percent. We teach you to build the site upfront, generate leads, and then oﬀer them to businesses, often with a free trial initially.
Q: If you're trying to show a business you have leads, do you run ads ﬁrst while you build the website? Because if you build a full website and then they say no, haven't you just wasted so much time? A: No, you're not wasting time because you're building a very generic website. If one business says no, there are other businesses out there that will potentially take the leads. You can ask the business that said no which of their competitors might be interested.
Q: How much is the course? Is the price quoted (6860 after discount) in US Dollars? A: Yes, that's US Dollars. (Agent then calculates the approximate Australian Dollar equivalent).
Q: If I was to pay in installments, like four installments, how would that work? A: It'll be just once a month for four months.
Q: When you started this, how long did it take? What happened in your ﬁrst 12 months? How much time were you putting in? A: I was putting in about an hour or two a day. Landed my ﬁrst client (paying $350/month) relatively quickly, which proved the concept. Within a year and a half, I reached $15,000 a month and quit my job.
Q: What support is available if I get overwhelmed or stuck? Will I get help? A: Yes, we're here to help you. I'm always here. We have a Facebook group where we go live every Tuesday and Thursday for Q&A. You can also connect with other members, including those in Australia.
Q: Being in Australia, since most members are in America, will I feel isolated or be at a disadvantage? A: You won't be isolated. We have 316 members in Australia alone. There's a ton of opportunity there, possibly less competition than in the US. The model works worldwide.
Q: Is the main way to ﬁnd clients just cold calling and oﬀering them the leads? A: Exactly. You don't have to know people; you can straight up cold call, oﬀer value (leads), and sign them up. Prospecting platforms like Yellow Pages or HomeAdvisor (where businesses already pay for shared leads) are also good sources.
Q: Who creates the initial ﬁve sites if I pay in full? A: Our team will build them for you once you decide on the niches.
Q: So, I could pick ﬁve diﬀerent niches, you guys build ﬁve diﬀerent websites, and then it's up to me to rank them and get the clients? A: Yes, and rank them as well.
Q: How long does it take to get the sites ranked? Like a month or two? A: Usually about three to ﬁve weeks.
Q: Are the websites editable by me? A: Yes, 100%. They'll be transferred to your account, and you can edit them.
Q: Can you tell me the payment amount in AUD? A: Eight thousand two hundred forty-four [dollars] seventy-nine [cents] (AUD 8244.79).
Q: Can I pay via bank transfer? A: Card payment is preferred as a bank transfer might not hit right away, delaying your login access.

Disc Comprehensive GuideThis guide is just a rule of thumb to maximize the cooperativeness of people when leading, persuading, and getting them to take actions that you want them to take. You can and should understand how to get a D to get into rapport with you, or make a C express their emotions. Treat these as guidelines to make things easier for you, but do not neglect advanced skills of forcing compliance out of types to get them to do things they are naturally uncomfortable doing. By being able to get that kind of investment out of them you enter a higher realm of sales skills, but these principles and be used as fundamentals to fall back upon, or as a base to build upon to gain the more advanced skills.Test With Rapport:There’s a spectrum of those giving and taking that determines a temperament of each. And that spectrum each contains positive and negative qualities. There is no pure type for the most part people are combinations but some aspects weigh more heavily than others.  D - Can be curt, 1 word answers may be rude, and cut you off to get straight to things. Look for one word responses and things of that nature.  I - Will jump right into the rapport with you and enjoy it immensely in a more higher energy way, going on long rants and you’ll almost be forced to get things back on track  S - Will build rapport is more chill and warm and normal, they won’t be as over the top as I’s but they’ll be okay with building some rapport with you naturally without you having to force it  C - Won’t come off rude like a D, won’t act over the top ready to dive into rapport like an I, and they’ll be reluctant to do rapport unlike and S who’ll accommodate. They have a lot of questions for you and want to dive into details, so they won’t be rude and cut you off or try to control the conversation aggressively like a D will, but the rapport won’t come out free ﬂowing they won’t give you a lot to work with when it comes to the conversation initially.Related Understandings:Directness - diCome on strong take the initiative and create a powerful ﬁrst impression, Indirect - scMore quite and reserved more easygoing or at least more self contained, ask more questions that give their opinions, the mistake might create negative self talk for days. They can act like a stubborn rock when they don’t want to crack. 
Open types - is open duh, focuses on feelings or statesGuarded Types - dc they prefer working with things or through people rather than with or for them, focuses on points, like to know where a conversation is going - idle chitchat is not for them  Adaptability:Higher Flexibility Personal Attitudes: Conﬁdence: Belief In ones Self, Trusting your own Judgement and Resourcefulness,Tolerance: Open Minded State of Acceptance, willingness to defer judgement on the basis of limited time or informationEmpathy: Sensitivity to another’s point of view, caring approach towards others without being overwhelmed or manipulated by people. Positiveness: Maintaining a state of positive expectations about people and situations. Including a positive state of energy in your thoughts and emotional patterns. Respect for others: Desire to understand, accept, and consider mutual and separate interests, Choices, and commitments,  Lower Flexibility Personal Attitudes:Rigidity, competition with others, discontent, being unapproachable, difﬁculty with dealing with ambiguity  Versatility:  Mental And Emotional Aptitudes:   Resilience: Learning how to cope in spite of setbacks, barriers or limited resourcesVision, Foresight, creativity & imagination, Attentiveness: Being mindful and aware of stimuli in the environment, reality focusedCompetence: Capability of managing required tasks and being knowledgable about required subjects and people, including uses and updates of appropriate abilities, self correction, able to 
initiate and evaluate by ones self, seeking feedback as appropriate, characterized by a problem solving mindset/approach to mattersLower versatility attitudes:Subjectiveness, bluntness, resistance, single mindedness, unreasonable risk taking, Flexibility:Higher Flexibility attitudes indicate: A higher level of security and sense of personal worth or wellbeing, an open minded searching attitude in dealing with people and situations. Positive expectations about your own goals and desired results, and those of others. Lower Flexibility attitudes indicate:A tendency to be reactive to people, conditions, or events. Often responding out of fear or anxiety. Predetermined views, conclusions, or patterns of behavior which are non negotiable. A tendency to be negative about what may occur. Especially if points of view or opinions change.  The best Leadership Style: Remember that there is no such thing as one best all purpose leadership style. Instead the best leaders are those that realize what a job role or speciﬁc situation requires for successful performance, and then ensures those outcomes. At times this may involve a clear cut match between your own strengths and the required actions. At other times behavior requirements may very. The effect leader may adapt his own natural style by using new behavior methods he has learned or may call upon other qualiﬁed individuals who’s talents and energies can more productively handle the immediate problem. Or a good leader will take action to modify the environment. This could include shifting the work priorities to ensure the successful completion of the necessary tasks without sacriﬁcing the wellbeing of other people.dd  DOMINANCEPriorities: getting immediate results, taking action, challenging self and othersMotivated by: power and authority, competition, winning, success, internally: the winFears: loss of control, being taken advantage of, vulnerabilityYou will notice: self-conﬁdence, directness, forcefulness, risk-takingLimitations: lack of concern for others, impatience, insensitivityTemperament: Active, Fast-paced, Assertive, Dynamic, BoldAction Plan: 
So you concerned with being number one, show them how to win, new opportunities, think logically, display reasoning, wants facts and highlights, provide concise data, strive for results, agree on goal and boundaries then support or get out of their way, likes personal choices, allow them to do their thing within limits, likes changes, very routines, prefers to delegate, looks for opportunities to modify their workload focus, wants others to notice and compliment them on accomplishments they have done, needs to be in charge, let them take the lead when appropriate - but give them parameters, tendency towards conﬂict, if necessary argue with conviction on points of disagreement backed up with facts, don’t argue on personality basis, Get right to the point, and decisively without getting bogged down in minute details, operate with conviction, know what you’re doing, and don’t try to bluff. You’re not cowering to them, you’re asserting yourself upon them which they want. Take opportunities during natural transition periods to build rapport, like if you have to pull up some paperwork, or if in person when you’re walking outside to check something out, or when you’re pulling something up to process payments, don’t do too much just show a bit of friendliness during those periods and when you’re transitioned into the next activity get right back into things. If they are reading or getting or doing something it’s okay to have the silence there to allow them to focus on getting the thing done they’re trying to ﬁnish, like if they’re ﬁlling out a form or something - don’t randomly feel a need to ﬁll the silence. Keeping a focus like this they’ll naturally start wanting to build rapport with you as the process deepens and they do business with you. Leadership Of them: Agree on the goal and specify the boundaries of the playing ﬁeld, then get out of their way. Ignore/be tolerant of their natural competitive spirit, and focus the energy on a common goal for bettering the organization or situation. They seek this sort of encouragement and feedback to function most effectively within the general framework of shared expectations. Coaching them: They like to learn the basic steps to quickly sift out what they want. In the interest of saving time they try to ﬁnd shortcuts, so show them the simplest fastest route to get them to their stated destination. They don’t bother with details it feels like wasting time they focus on results. Focus on the high points. Only the details to get something to work so they can move on to the next thing. They want to manage you, let them take the reigns and feel empowered on certain things clearly.Getting them to Decide: They tend to make autonomous no nonsense decisions. If the decision will help them meet their goals they go for it, if not they typically say no. One of the few times they’ll procrastinate in reaching a conclusion is when it’ll take too much time or effort to do the homework to determine the best alternative. You can prevent this procrastination by simply providing a brief analysis for each option you present to them.Motivating them: Provide them with options and clearly describe the probabilities of success in achieving goals “Ross, here are 4 possibilities for developing the Evans estate. I’ve highlighted the key points for each suggestion and included costs for each projection on the bottom of each one. The choice is yours.” They gravitate to situations where they can take charge and win. On tennis courts they’re arguing with refs. They gravitate to the leadership positions. It’s not how you play the game it’s winning more that anything else that motivates them. Complimenting them: Mention their achievements, upward mobility, and leadership potential, omit personal comments and focus on their track record. “Jones, you’ve exceeded our company goals every quarter for the last year. And have put in more hours than anybody but the top ofﬁcials here. The CEO has his eye on you for the next upcoming vice presidential slot.” Counseling Them: Stick to the facts, draw them out by talking about the desired results then discuss their concerns, focus on tasks more than feelings, ask them how they would solve the problem,  “Anne, we’ve heard a few comments that need to be addressed. We’ve heard some of our employees don’t feel appreciated for the extra hours they’ve been putting in for you on the Evan’s project. They say they’ve given up social engagements and work 14 hour days to meet their deadline. How do you think we can bolster their morale?”Correcting Them: Describe what results are desired, show them the gap between actual and desired, suggest clearly the improvement that is needed, and establish a time when they will get back to you. “We need to streamline communication around here so that one hand know what the other hand is doing. Last month we had two separate divisions calling on the same corporate CEO for donations. I want you to come up with a plan so that we know what who’s working on so that we don’t duplicate our efforts. Get back to me by the end of the week.”Communicating With Them: Be prepared to listen to their suggestions, the course of action they have in mind and the general results they are considering. This enables you to begin on a 
positive note by indicating the areas in which you already agree. Then you can work backwards towards gaining agreement on the results you both want, and are willing to either mutually or independently allow the other to achieve. “Sarah, this format will give you the freedom to develop your branch your way and still allow Vern and Ellen to structure their’s another way. Without sacriﬁcing time or morale.” Making decisions and problem solving with them: They’ll want to provide their own initial view on the decision to be made or problem to be solved and the process they’d prefer to follow in reaching a clear cut preferably quickly chosen solution. “As I see it, you have the most experience in organizing seminars like this Charles. So why don’t you throw out a few ideas? You can anticipate where possible and be open to summarizing the achievements you’ve made." Or, possibly in a case like where you have a lack of achievement in this area. “Hal you ﬂatter me, but I’ve never undertaken and international convention like this before. As for ideas, why don’t we decide who wants to perform which function and then we can all do what we feel comfortable doing. With this approach you’r most likely to reach mutual agreement with the least hassle for everyone concerned, yourself included. When suggesting a different idea, opinion, or action to them: Be sure to point out you are trying to work in ways that are acceptable to them and also yourself. Focus on your desire to identify solutions that will also meet their expectations. Stress that you don’t want to cause difﬁculties for either them or you. “Phil, instead of writing this report as it occurs to you, and me… I’d rather write an outline ﬁrst and then the rapport. I know it takes longer initially, but it saves time in the long run because the writing will be better organized and make more sense to the readers.”When Acknowledging them, when it’s appropriate to reward or reinforce their behaviors: focus on how pleased you are, assume they are also pleased with the desired outcome in that situation. Also mention how glad you are to be a part of that process working with them to make things better for both of you through cooperation. Bottom line each of you gets better results by combining your energies on a common targeted goal. “Phil, this rapport turned out much better with your wonderful anecdotes and asides. Now we have something that’s interesting, clear, and well organized.”Delegating to them: Give them the bottom line and then let them do their thing so that they can be more efﬁcient, give them parameters guidelines, and deadlines. “We need to get that mall built a month sooner or we’ll lose our shirts. 14 tenants are threatening to bail out of their contracts if we don’t open in time for the holidays. Don’t spend more than another $30k keep everything legal and out of the newspapers and get back to me by Monday morning.”

Gain Security Through: Playfulness, other’s approval Measures Personal Worth By: acknowledgement, applause, complimentsAppearance: Fashionable, StylishSeeks: RecognitionStrength: Persuading, Enthusiastic, EntertainingWeaknesses/Growth Areas: Inattentive to Detail, short begin attention span, low follow throughIrritations: routines, complexityUnder Stress: Sarcastic, superﬁcial Decision Making Pattern: spontaneousOccupation: Sales, public relations, actorLeadership Of them: Help them focus their abilities, with their energy and enthusiasm they might get involved a bunch of stuff and either accomplish a lot or show ﬂurries of activity while getting nothing done in a signiﬁcant way. Channel it with tactful reminders and hands on assistance to help them prioritize and organize. They’ll let you know when they feel off or having off days and you can give them verbal boosts and personalized attention. Coaching them: Don’t give them too much or they can become overwhelmed. Skip as much of the detailed boring stuff as possible. Get them involved. They’re typically kinesthetic hands on learners so let them try by ﬁrst getting a feel for what’s involved, and then showing you what they understood so you can give them structured feedback. Frequently they want to jump in and try before they’re ready. Or before they fully understand everything. Allow them to save face when they do something wrong, and heap on compliments when they get it right. Prioritizing with them: Many ﬁnd that sorting out priorities and solutions becomes very difﬁcult when too many opportunities bombard them. When this happens they may become characteristically mute and immobilized. Temporarily. Other people can help by prioritizing items for them to tackle. When other people organize task for them their anxiety level lessens even though they don’t like organization. Getting them to Decide: Support their dreams: They operate from a predominantly multi focus right brain perspective. They see mental picture ﬁrst then convert those pictures to words. Preferring main ideas and generalities not details they base decisions on their impulses gut feelings and other’s recommendations and testimonials. Emotions rule. It’s not they don’t use logic or facts, but feelings and emotion comes ﬁrst. Thinking is a servant to their feeling state. Be more enthusiastic show you’re interested in them by letting them talk, by using more animation in your own gestures and voice, and illustrate your ideas using stories or mental pictures that relate to him and his goals. They like to interact to try to to hurry the discussion. Include opportunities for small talk and getting personally acquainted. They like to envision the big 
picture to generally less motivated by many facts and details they respond better to short overviews or capsule summaries of what you plan to cover. Attempt to develop some stimulating enjoyable ideas together while focusing on supporting their opinions and dreams. They turn off to people who douse their dreams. Then support their ideas by showing them how they can turn their talk into action. If you disagree try not to argue because they dislike conﬂict. You might not win the argument anyway because their strong suit is feelings and intuition. If trapped the can twist people around through very clever manipulation of feelings with their usage of words and emotions. Try to explore alternate solutions instead. When you reach an agreement iron out the speciﬁc details concerning what when, who, where, how. Then document the agreement with them since they tend to naturally forget such details.Motivating them: They like special packages and a little something extra to inspire them to go the whole 9 yards. (If you do x I’ll give you y!) Or, show them how they can look good in the eyes of others. (When you close your next order that’ll be you’re 10th order this year, you can all but clinch that presidents award for achievement this year at the annual rewards ceremony! The big boss himself will see that!) Contests and rewards work, but with them they may sprint towards a quick win the ﬁrst week or so and then they’ll tell themselves they have a whole year to win a contest if it’s something too far away and they they take their foot off the gas and get sidetracked by other things and do nothing about it until the week before the contest ends and then try to sprint to the ﬁnish within the last week or so. To keep up their motivation give them shorter contests with smaller pay-offs culminating in the big win at the end. Counseling Them: Give them ample opportunity to talk about whatever may be bothering them. Pay attention to both facts, and feelings - buy put your primary emphasis on their feelings. Ask probing questions and involve them by asking how they can solve the challenge or difﬁculty. Sometimes just airing their feelings and thoughts relieves tension for these individuals. Talking allows them to get something off of their chest, and even can become and end in itself because their energy is largely inﬂuenced by the quality of their relationship with a person.   Correcting Them: When stress hits them they prefer looking the other way and searching for more positive upbeat experiences. They avoid problems as long as they can. If the pressure persists they tend to literally walk away from the problem. When this tactic fails they may become emotionally candid in attempts to meet their needs. (I can’t believe I let this happen, but I brought it all upon myself) Sometimes stress manifests itself in animated panic. Let these individuals know speciﬁcally what the challenge happens to be. Deﬁne the behavior that can eliminate it & conﬁrm the mutually agreeable action plan in writing to prevent future misunderstandings. Since they prefer keeping the conversation light avoid what they view as negative or distasteful approaches. Rather than (why did your sales drop off 50% last month?) Use more optimistically stated questions like (How’d you like to bolster your sales up to your normal range and beyond it?) They’d simply rather deal with things going right. Communicating With Them: Be prepared to listen to their personal feelings and experiences. Since they have a need to be both expressive and able to share their emotions with others. Their style requires open and responsive interaction with others preferable in a manner of congenial 
and unhurried conversation. It’s much like that between long time friends. (Just between me and you… I feel very uneasy about x)Making decisions and problem solving with them: They’ll want to avoid a discussion of more complex negative sounding or otherwise messy problem situations. It’s difﬁcult for them to feel positive or agreeable with you or anyone else under these circumstances. In making decisions with them they will be open to your suggestions as long as these ideas will allow them to look and feel good and not require a lot of follow up detail work or long term commitment. (You know just about everybody who’s anybody…since we need to get x by date, why not go ahead and wrap up all your calls by date? - then you can relax a lot more next week) When suggesting a different idea, opinion, or action to them: Be sure to point out you are doing it that way if it’s acceptable to them. Focus on their desire to identify solutions that will also meet their expectations. Stress that you don’t want to cause difﬁculties for either them or you, above all offer your suggestions as gifts that can make this situation, tasks, or relationship easier and more beneﬁcial to them as well as to other people who you feel are also likely to ﬁnd this very acceptable and desirable. (You’re lucky I’m on the nominating committee. So many people wanted the hospitality position that I couldn’t manage it for you this year, but I think I got one that’s even better than that. How about Junior high dances?) Complimenting them: Pay direct personal compliments to them as individuals when legitimately deserved. Mention their charm friendliness, creative ideas, persuasiveness and/or appearance. Better yet, all of the above. While other types respond to more speciﬁc job related comments they can mentally relive more global generalizations for weeks to come. (We are so lucky to have you with us, you’re a real gem.)When Acknowledging them, and when it’s appropriate to reward or reinforce their behaviors: Focus on how glad you are they have succeeded in ﬁnding a pleasant solution to their concern or objective. In addition let them know how much you appreciate them for their openness and willingness to be responsive to you in a way that allows everyone to end up feeling good about the results afterwards. (George, I’m so glad we could reach a solution that both you and I feel good about. I appreciate your openness about only being able to call perspective donors on friday night. That’s ﬁne with me, we’ll work this out so that everyone is happy.) Delegating to them: Make sure to receive clear agreement. Set up checkpoints/times to avoid long stretches with no progress rapports. Otherwise they’ll lapse into their natural way of doing things. Spontaneously completing particulars which feel best while postponing less stimulating tasks especially those that involve follow up and checking.They’re good for maintaining group morale and brainstorming. Get their opinions and assistance and present to them activities that draw attention and recognition to themselves appeals to them. Concept people who come up with plenty of ideas but not the means of carrying them out. So steer them into ways that assure the implementation of those ideas.

Coaching/developing them: When they’re in training for a job or something they prefer one on one hands on instruction with a real live human being starting at the beginning and ending at the end. By learning each step they become generally more comfortable with their functions, during training and other newer situations they tend to observe others for a longer than average time. When they feel they can do a task then and only then will the comfortably begin. This slower pace can frustrate dominant and inﬂuencers, both of whom like to plunge right into things whether they’ve done them before or not. Understand that they need to do things slowly and this will re-assure the faster paced types that the job will get done. Get ready to be ready with them. Have a step by step list of procedures or a working timetable/schedule at your disposal. They need to feel secure in their mastery of procedures until their actions become second nature and more routine. At the same time, they prefer a pleasant and patient approach while they learn what’s expected of them. Motivating them: Besides thinking they can learn to master a series of procedures they like to also feel that their relationship with others can beneﬁt from their follow through. (If you can learn to use this computer by next week, you can send the whole Christmas mailing for mr. Hawkins on monday - then he can go to Texas for his family reunion) Or show them how to 
strengthen their relationships with others. (When this ofﬁce makes it’s 1000th sale, it can win the outstanding division award for the year, and you can help that happen by getting Mr. Aarons to look at this new demographic data.) Focus on what’s important now. Avoid procrastination and/or hoping others will do things for them. Practice and perfectCounseling Them: Allow plenty of time to explore their thoughts and feelings so you can understand the emotional side of the situation. They usually express their feelings less directly so draw them out through questioning and listening responses. Bear in mind this type tends to balk at sudden change whether the change is good or bad. The key point is that their stability motivated state is disrupted by the unknown. You can help reduce their fears by showing how speciﬁc changes will beneﬁt them and their company. (Barbra, moving to Dallas will be an adjustment, for all of us at ﬁrst but 80% of our staff has agreed to go. The company will move you and your family, sell your house, ad more medical and dental beneﬁts to your health plan and give you a 10% bonus for loyal service. We like to take care, do the unpleasant as well as the fun things for our own, and you are a valuable trusted employee. And besides, you’ll still be with many of the same friends coworkers and the company you’ve always been with day in and day out.)   Correcting Them: Reassure them that you only want to correct a speciﬁc behavior. They tend to take things personally, so remove the something is wrong with you barrier as quickly as possible. Don’t blame or judge the person, keep the conversation focused on the behavior and it’s appropriateness. If the problem involves a procedure help them learn how to improve it. Point out in a non threatening way what they’re already doing right while also emphasizing what needs changing. (Norma I admire your persistence on this proposal, but we have to add more details to the idea section before we send it out. For example…) Communicating With Them: Be ready to do more talking than listening with them. They don’t naturally feel comfortable when the limelight is focused on them. You’ll want to clarify any key agenda item with them. Working to stay organized, and moving forward stedily but slowly as you check to make sure that they both, understand, and accept what is being said. (Did you want me to stick around the ofﬁce at a particular time each day in case you need to telephone me in case of emergency questions on this account or do you want me to call you?)Making decisions and problem solving with them: In dealing with problems and decisions with them make sure to deal with 1 subject or situation at a time, one step at a time. To gain clarity, before moving on to other items make sure they are ready willing and able to do so. Recalling that they need stability deal with matters calmly and in a more relaxed manner, encourage them to share their suggestions as to how the decision might be made in a way that is likely to add even more stability to the current conditions that already or previously exist. (Would you mind writing down a schedule of your ofﬁces activities so I can get my proposal written up without missing anything) When suggesting a different idea, opinion, or action to them: Point out how you are trying to identify ways that you can help continue to make things pleasant for them. You simply have an idea or opinion in this respect which will also help stabilize your own relationship expectations 
with them, which is important to you too. (I know we initially agreed on 10 phone calls per day, but some of our volunteers are unable to make that commitment, would you be comfortable making 15 calls a day if those calls included your personal friends and family?) Complimenting them: Mention their teamwork and dependability, (Pam besides plugging along on this project for two years I really appreciate the fact that you’ve encouraged everyone else to do their part, we couldn’t have done it without you) or remark how others regard the, how well they get along with co-workers, and how important their relationship efforts have been to the company. (Name, you’ve been the glue holding this place together for the last 20 years.) Effusiveness can arouse their suspicions so stick to praising what they’ve done rather more abstract personal attributes. Otherwise their modesty and your vagueness may cause them to dismiss your comments. When Acknowledging them, and when it’s appropriate to reward or reinforce their behaviors: Focus on how you genuinely and sincerely appreciate their willingness to make things good for you and others. Approach matters in a more systematic low keyed and understandable manner Also, point out how you’ve noticed they make important contributions when they take the initiative to share their own ideas interests and insights in helping make sure that these results are achieved. (Just say anything about the impending merger that you want to share. We certainly don’t want to use any high pressure tactics which is precisely why you meet our own expectations so well. Thank you very much for your willingness to provide us with this valuable input) Delegating to them: They may be reluctant to ask others to do their own share of the work. So you can make a personal appeal to their loyalty and sense of sportsmanship (Al, you’re an example for this company of genuine cooperative spirit. Your staff wants to please you so by giving everyone in your department just 10 of those names to call, you can all reach the goal together by noon tomorrow. Otherwise, you’ll probably have a lot more difﬁculty reaching all of those people by the target date.) Give them the task, state the deadlines that need to be met, and explain why it’s important to do it that way.
